questiontext.text: Which five words (excluding stop words) are the most common in Moby Dick?

generalfeedback.text:
We extract the information using

MobyDick_raw <- filter( Books, title == "Moby Dick" )

MobyDick_raw %>% 
  unnest_tokens( word, text ) %>%
  mutate( word = gsub( "_", "", word ) ) %>%
  count( word, sort=TRUE ) %>%
  anti_join( stop_words, by="word" ) %>%
  slice_head( n=5 )

We find that whale, ahab, sea, ship and ye are the five most common words (excluding stop words).

questiontext.text: When considering a corpus which only includes Moby Dick and The Life and Adventures of Robinson Crusoe, which five words have the highest term frequency - inverse document frequency (tf-idf)?

generalfeedback.text:
We can use the bind_tf_idf() function as seen in the Section 4.3.2:

Books %>%
  unnest_tokens( word, text ) %>% 
  mutate( word = gsub( "_", "", word ) ) %>% 
  count( title, word, sort=TRUE ) %>%
  bind_tf_idf( word, title, n ) %>%
  arrange( desc(tf_idf) ) %>%
  slice_head( n=10 )

The output shows that “whale”, “ahab”, “friday”, “sperm” and “stubb” have the highest term frequency - inverse document frequency. Here we ignore the word “whales” because it’s the plural of a word with higher tf-idf.

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements is correct when you explore the proportions with which the different topics feature?

generalfeedback.text:
We first extract the estimated proportions:

Articles_topics <- tidy( Articles_LDA , matrix = "gamma" ) %>% 
  separate( document, c("NewsType", "ID"), sep="_", convert=TRUE )

We can now create a box plot of proportions for each of the articles

ggplot( Articles_topics, aes( x=factor(topic), y=gamma ) ) + 
  facet_wrap( ~NewsType ) + geom_boxplot() + 
  labs( x="Topic", y="Proportion" )

We find that articles from “business” category are usually made up of 25% Topic 1 and 75% Topic 2. The reverse is true for the “sports” category. So we find that that Topic 1 is featuring significantly less in articles in the “business” category.

answer.text: Topic 1 is featuring significantly more in articles in the “business” category
Topic 1 is featuring significantly less in articles in the “business” category
There is no real difference between the “sports” and “business” category in terms of how often Topic 1 features

questiontext.text: Which of the following words are among the five most common words for one of the two topics?

generalfeedback.text:
We can extract the five most common words in each of the two topics using

tidy( Articles_LDA , matrix = "beta" ) %>%
group_by( topic ) %>%
slice_max( beta, n=5 )

So we find that for Topic 1, the most common words are “Pakistan”, “world”, “test”, “England”, “cricket”. So it seems quite a lot of articles are reports about cricket.

For Topic 2, the most common words are “percent”, “oil”, “million”, “prices”, “strong”, which seems more related to business.

So we see that the difference in topics identified in part b) is also reflected in the frequency of the different words used within the topics.
